author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Nick Kyrgios Show, Also Known as Wimbledon, Gets Another Encore
description: Kyrgios, the big, talented Australian, has taken over Wimbledon with his antics and psychological warfare. It’s working.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Going up against the tennis talents of Nick Kyrgios, the powerful Australian with hands as soft as a masseuse’s, is plenty difficult in its own right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Knopper
title: Kool & the Gang Get the Dance Floor Moving. Have They Gotten Their Due?
description: The group’s funk, disco and pop songs have been sampled over 1,800 times, but haven’t collected the same accolades as many contemporaries. A new boxed set takes a look back.
content: “Do something,” the producer Gene Redd instructed the drummer George Brown and the bassist Robert “Kool” Bell during an early recording session in New York. “Say something! Sing something.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: For Francis, a Papacy Complicated by the Shadow of Resignation
description: Benedict’s exit changed expectations that the papacy would always be a lifetime assignment, fueling speculation the current pope has tried to push away.
content: ROME — Over the last few weeks, close watchers of the Roman Catholic Church have carefully studied shadows on the Vatican walls for proof that Pope Francis is about to retire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Mother of Strange Fashion
description: A new exhibition in Paris on the designer Elsa Schiaparelli shows how her Surrealist “little jokes” still inspire weirdness today.
content: PARIS — A woman wears a long thermometer on a hook hanging from her ear, her chin upturned and eyes gently closed, in a photograph taken by the artist Man Ray around 1920, not long after the influenza pandemic of 1918.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 4, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 4, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Where the Risks of Pregnancy Meet Abortion Laws and Health Care
description: Even before the wave of abortion bans, medical treatment and advice for pregnancy has largely focused on fetal safety over the mother’s.
content: As the United States has grappled with the unfolding consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overruling Roe v. Wade, one question lurks between the lines of court opinions and news stories alike: Why are the risks of pregnancy so rarely discussed anywhere, even though that information is relevant not just to individual decisions but to policies about abortion, pregnancy, and health care for women?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Posts First Monthly Trade Deficit in 30 Years
description: High energy prices and disrupted supply chains dent the image of “Made in Germany,” as May imports exceeded exports for the first time in decades.
content: BERLIN — For the first time in more than three decades, Germany has posted a monthly trade deficit, the most recent sign that Europe’s largest economy is facing stress because of interrupted supply chains and record energy prices linked to Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Walker
title: The Founders Bequeathed Us Something Radical
description: Why a culture that has bred cynicism and placed a premium on the performance of virtue is in need of new ideas to build a better America.
content: The heart does not exactly swell with patriotic pride this Independence Day, as the gut absorbs one dizzying, disorienting blow after the next. Our sense of who we are, our very identity as Americans, feels assaulted and violated. Amid profound, painful regression on issue after issue, we are left gasping for breath.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Strategic Shift in Bid to Regain Abortion Rights
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 4, 2022.
content: “We’re in a chess game and we haven’t gotten checkmate. We’re doing check, check, check, check. Unfortunately, we’re doing check, check, check with pregnant people and their families’ lives.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Chosen Families
description: Spending the holiday with those who support you.
content: Today, as we observe the Fourth of July holiday in the U.S., I’m thinking about the permutations of family, the people we invite to the cookout, the ones we’ll be watching the fireworks with. Perhaps you’ll be with your parents and siblings, your kids, your kids’ kids. Perhaps you’ll gather with close friends, with neighbors, reunite with your pandemic pod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Metrokin
title: How to Protect Bristol Bay’s Salmon for the Long Haul
description: E.P.A. action, legislation and land conservation together can permanently protect Alaska’s Bristol Bay, the salmon and a way of life.
content: ANCHORAGE — Bristol Bay is a place defined by salmon. For those of us who live and work in this region of wetlands, rivers and tundra, our lives revolve around this amazing fish. This spring the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a ban on the disposal of mining waste — a widely celebrated move to protect the bay and its salmon from the infamous Pebble Mine project, which has sought to extract precious metals from beneath the bay for decades. But this ban, while powerful, will not, on its own, fully protect Bristol Bay if it’s approved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Another Step Toward Climate Apocalypse
description: The Supreme Court does its bit to make the earth unlivable.
content: We’re having a heat wave, a tropical heat wave. Also a temperate heat wave and an Arctic heat wave, with temperatures reaching the high 80s in northern Norway. The megadrought in the Western United States has reduced Lake Mead to a small fraction of its former size, and it now threatens to become a “dead pool” that can no longer supply water to major cities. Climate change is already doing immense damage, and it’s probably only a matter of time before we experience huge catastrophes that take thousands of lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Nazi Tapes Provide a Chilling Sequel to the Eichmann Trial
description: Sixty years after the execution of Adolf Eichmann, the logistics chief of the Holocaust, an Israeli documentary airs his confessions in his own voice.
content: TEL AVIV — Six decades after the historic trial in Jerusalem of Adolf Eichmann, one of the chief engineers of the Holocaust, a new Israeli documentary series has delivered a dramatic coda: the boastful confessions of the Nazi war criminal, in his own voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden and Maria Cramer
title: At Nathan’s Hot Dog Contest, One Champion Keeps His Title and Another Reclaims Hers
description: Joey Chestnut secured his 15th win, while Miki Sudo won back her title in the women’s contest after sitting out in 2021 to have a baby.
content: One competitor won his 15th contest in a row and another reclaimed her title as the world’s top ranked female eater during the Nathan’s Famous International Hot Dog Eating Contest on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Libresco Sargeant
title: In a Post-Roe World, We Can Avoid Pitting Mothers Against Babies
description: Especially in hard cases like ectopic pregnancy, we can offer more love and material support to mothers and children.
content: Now that the Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade, states face a new reality about where to draw the line in pregnancy for when abortion is permitted. In these debates, ectopic pregnancy is a key issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Russia Advances Behind Brutal Barrage, but Will Its Strategy Keep Working?
description: The Russian and Ukrainian armies have both been badly mauled, raising questions about how long they can keep fighting as they have, particularly the outgunned Ukrainians.
content: Russia’s capture of the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, a significant victory for Moscow’s campaign to conquer eastern Ukraine, demonstrates the success of the Russian military’s grinding strategy based on superior firepower and incremental advances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: What Becomes a Star Most? For Tom Cruise, It’s Control.
description: Sheer force of will is now part of his potent mix of athleticism and charisma. That combination goes a long way to explain why “Top Gun: Maverick” is a hit.
content: “In order to do my job,” Ben Stiller, as Tom Cruise’s stunt double Tom Crooze, muses in a video made for the 2000 MTV Movie Awards, “I have to ask myself: Who is Tom Cruise? What is Tom Cruise? Why is Tom … Cruise?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Walter
title: Meet Joan of Arc, Action Hero
description: In her new novel, Katherine Chen puts a fresh spin on the oft-examined life of the girl who saved France.
content: It’s hard to name a historical figure who has inspired more writers than Joan of Arc. Yet it’s equally difficult to imagine a character more incomprehensible to the modern ear than the 15th-century French mystic, martyr and war hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasmina Nielsen, Emma Bubola and Euan Ward
title: Mall Shooting Shocks Denmark on a Joyful Summer Weekend
description: The suspect in the attack that killed 3 people was known to mental health services, the police said, and the victims appeared to be random.
content: COPENHAGEN — It was a festive weekend in Denmark, as Danes cheered on the unusual spectacle of the Tour de France starting in their country, listened to the Strokes at the Roskilde music festival, and hiked, picnicked, shopped and enjoyed the summer sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Lara Jakes
title: Bullet Too Damaged to Prove Who Killed Palestinian American Journalist, U.S. Says
description: The State Department said Shireen Abu Akleh, the Al Jazeera broadcaster killed in the West Bank in May, was likely hit by shots fired from Israeli military positions.
content: JERUSALEM — The bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh, the Palestinian American journalist shot in the occupied West Bank in May, was most likely fired from Israeli military lines but was too damaged to say for sure, the State Department said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Mass Shooting Near Chicago
description: Plus Russia regroups in the east and China arrests a mysterious tycoon.
content: At least six people have been killed in a mass shooting at an Independence Day parade in Highland Park, Ill., an affluent, mostly white suburb north of Chicago. The police said at least two dozen more people were injured yesterday. Here are live updates on the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: What’s on TV This Week: Macy’s Fireworks and ‘America Outdoors With Baratunde Thurston’
description: The annual fireworks display airs on NBC. And a new outdoor adventure series has its debut on PBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanveer Badal
title: A Refreshing Look at Egypt’s Ancient Pyramids
description: A downpour, a dust storm and an encounter with a lively dig team offered a photographer a new perspective on the country’s celebrated tombs.
content: “Yallah, yallah, yallah! Woooo!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A Damp Independence Day Weekend Continues for Much of the Country
description: Heavy rainfall and thunderstorms are in the forecast for a large portion of the United States, with the potential for hail the size of golf balls in Montana.
content: A mixed bag of severe weather and dangerously hot temperatures was expected for parts of the United States on Independence Day, after Tropical Storm Colin doused the Carolinas over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francisco Cantú
title: Our Gun Myths Have Held America Hostage for Too Long
description: Proponents of gun reform in this country are up against more than a powerful gun lobby. They are up against our most durable national myth.
content: Like so many Americans, I have been called into relationships with guns since I was a child and have been made to understand, even long before I could articulate it, that guns represented something essential about what it means to become a fully realized American man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Longing for Roger Federer at Wimbledon
description: Federer said he hoped to return to the tournament he has won eight times before. His absence from the field this year left a void over Wimbledon’s early rounds.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — There he was, a surprise, perhaps the biggest of this Wimbledon fortnight: Roger Federer in the flesh Sunday on Centre Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Malloch-Brown
title: The World Needs More Than Crumbs From the G7’s Table
description: The Group of 7 missed a chance to act, but it’s not too late.
content: The Group of 7 summit in Germany ended last week with leaders of the world’s richest countries pledging to support Ukraine for “as long as it takes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Joe Turkel, the Spectral Bartender in ‘The Shining,’ Dies at 94
description: Also memorably seen in “Blade Runner,” he was a favorite among directors looking for someone who could bring zealous professionalism to even the smallest role.
content: Joe Turkel, a gaunt-faced yeoman character actor who appeared in scores of movies but is best known for two of his final performances — as Lloyd the bartender in “The Shining” and Dr. Eldon Tyrell in “Blade Runner” — died on June 27 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: When Will Federer and the Williams Sisters Call It Quits? Maybe Never.
description: Advances in physical preparation keep their bodies in the game, and so can the changing nature of sports business and celebrity.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Most tennis professionals are retired by their mid-30s. But last week, there was Serena Williams, at almost 41, grinding against a competitor a little more than half her age for more than three hours at Wimbledon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Rachel Wisniewski
title: ‘Swimming Wasn’t for Us’
description: The nation’s first Black-owned pool club aims to teach hundreds of children to swim this summer, helping to close a dangerous racial gap in the process.
content: YEADON, Pa. — On a hot summer afternoon in 1959, hundreds of Black families in this little town just outside Philadelphia gathered on Union Avenue to cool off and make some history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A four-bedroom house in San Diego, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1929 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles.
content: This house is 10 minutes from Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve, 1,750 acres of rugged coastline with a lagoon and walking trails that draw locals and tourists. Also nearby is Torrey Pines State Beach, a public beach popular with surfers, and Torrey Pines Golf Course, the site of regular PGA Tour events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Joy Dong
title: Zhang Sizhi, Lawyer Who Defended Chinese Dissidents, Dies at 94
description: He shed tears over the challenge of defending clients in a system stacked against them. But even in defeat, admirers said, he set a lasting example.
content: Zhang Sizhi, a Chinese lawyer who defended politically contentious clients, including Mao Zedong’s underlings, Tiananmen-era dissidents, purged officials and victims of police frame-ups, inspiring generations of human rights lawyers with his advocacy, died on June 24 in Beijing. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Five Years After Vanishing, Chinese Canadian Billionaire Faces Trial
description: The case against the financier Xiao Jianhua is widely seen as part of a crackdown on the debt-fueled excess that drove China’s economic growth.
content: More than five years after his mysterious disappearance from a luxury hotel in Hong Kong, a Chinese Canadian billionaire and onetime trusted financier to China’s political elite has been put on trial in a case that epitomizes the ruling Communist Party’s efforts to rein in an earlier era of freewheeling capitalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: How Can We Still Be Talking About Trump?
description: Biden can’t possibly like the chatter about him, either.
content: Gail Collins: Happy Independence Day, Bret! Want to celebrate by talking about the Supreme Court?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Adjusts His Cabinet, Seeking a Fresh Start
description: The new appointments by President Emmanuel Macron of France are unlikely to help him push his agenda through a fragmented lower house of Parliament.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France lightly shuffled his cabinet on Monday in a bid to jump start his second term, weeks after elections that significantly weakened his parliamentary majority and bolstered his political opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: The Mets May Finally Get Their Aces Back
description: Jacob deGrom’s first rehab start went well, and Max Scherzer is slated to return to the starting rotation on Tuesday. Will that be enough to offset an offensive downturn?
content: The struggling Mets got yet another dose of optimism on Sunday when Jacob deGrom, the team’s co-ace who has been sidelined all season, struck out five of the six batters he faced in a rehab start for Class A St. Lucie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Army Bases That Honor Confederate Traitors Could Soon Be Renamed for These Heroes
description: The names “embody the best of the United States Army and America,” a commission established by Congress wrote in announcing its choices.
content: WASHINGTON — During the Jim Crow era, nine Southern Army bases were named for treasonous Confederate generals who fought to preserve slavery and white supremacy. Now a commission established by Congress has suggested new names for the bases that “embody the best of the United States Army and America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Clifford L. Alexander, Adviser to Presidents, Is Dead at 88
description: He was the first Black secretary of the Army — just one of many jobs, both high- and low-profile, that he held over nearly 20 years in government.
content: Clifford L. Alexander Jr., whose long career as a leading adviser to Democratic presidents ranged from working behind the scenes on landmark legislation like the Voting Rights Act to high-profile roles like serving as the first Black secretary of the Army, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Two Homes That Nourish a Family’s Many Creative Pursuits
description: A businesswoman with a husband, three children, three restaurants and a publishing venture has a home upstate and a studio in Manhattan to make it all work.
content: Before Hurricane Sandy, Nhi Mundy had a good life in the financial district with her family. She and her husband, Michael Mundy, were raising three children while he worked as a photographer and she partnered with him to start “An Afternoon With,” a blog that featured intimate images of individuals and families in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabra Boyd
title: A 2,700-Mile Cycling Race Is Now Even More Extreme
description: The Tour Divide, a bikepacking race from the Canadian Rockies to the U.S. border with Mexico, has always been a test of fortitude. But extreme weather is making it much more dangerous.
content: Kevin Latta pushed his bike forward, following the Bull River down a ridge in the Canadian Rockies. The tire tracks from riders ahead of him had disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Keep Czars Far Away, in Moscow or Mar-a-Lago
description: Things worth fighting for on the Fourth of July.
content: A great-grandfather on my mother’s side had a big mouth. The trait seems to run in the family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A Russian assault on eastern Ukraine.
content: Lysychansk, the last major city held by Ukraine in the eastern province of Luhansk, has fallen, giving Moscow a victory in its campaign to capture the Donbas, a mineral-rich region bordering Russia. Pressure is now redoubling on the U.S. and its allies to get the more powerful weapons they have promised Ukraine to the front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: She Inspired ‘A League of Their Own.’ At 95, She’s Far From Done.
description: Maybelle Blair is still dedicated to including women and girls in baseball. And she still loves the “clicketyclack” sound of baseball cleats on her feet.
content: Maybelle Blair walked into a sporting goods store in her early 90s with a mission: to try on a pair of spikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In This Debut Novel, Family Ties Bind, Even From Afar
description: Taymour Soomro’s “Other Names for Love” is about a Pakistani teenager sent abroad to be educated who does not want to come back, even when sorely needed.
content: One of the great things about writing is that, in the end, it doesn’t matter where you came from or went to school. Walt Whitman, Jessica Mitford, Truman Capote, Maya Angelou and Hart Crane had not a semester of college between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: In Putin’s Russia, the Arrests Are Spreading Quickly and Widely
description: One by one, Russians deemed insufficiently patriotic are being snatched up by security forces as the Kremlin tightens the noose.
content: They came for Dmitri Kolker, an ailing physicist, in the intensive care ward. They came for Ivan Fedotov, a hockey star, as he was leaving practice with a film crew in tow. They came for Vladimir Mau, a state university rector, the week he was re-elected to the board of Gazprom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: No Guns, No Dragons: Her Video Games Capture Private Moments
description: Nina Freeman, a leading indie game designer, infuses her work with a poetic sensibility far from the tone of mainstream shoot-’em-ups.
content: Growing up in Ipswich, Mass., Nina Freeman spent a lot of time playing video games with a pair of close friends, twin sisters whose basement served as an arena for marathon sessions. “My friends and I were nerds,” she recalled. “We played a lot of games. ‘Final Fantasy 11’ was like a second life to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Burns
title: America Is Failing Refugees, and Itself
description: How the United States treats refugees is one of the greatest tests of the American experiment.
content: For his 1985 documentary about the Statue of Liberty, the filmmaker Ken Burns interviewed two Jewish boys sitting on a bench in New York City. They were twins who had fled Ukraine, then part of the Soviet Union, with their father. Like generations of refugees before them and generations since, they had arrived in the United States hoping for a better life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauntel Lowe
title: Brittney Griner to Biden: ‘I’m Terrified I Might Be Here Forever.’
description: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, sent a letter to President Biden on Monday, asking him to help free her from prison in Russia. She has been in custody since February.
content: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia on drug charges since February, sent a handwritten letter to President Biden on Monday asking him not to forget about her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Updated Covid Shots Are Coming. Will They Be Too Late?
description: The government has greenlit new vaccines to defend against the latest Omicron variants. But the shots won’t arrive until the fall, and cases are rising now.
content: Roseann Renouf, 77, has grown tired of the current generation of coronavirus shots. Having “never been one for a lot of vaccination,” she decided to forgo the latest round of boosters after watching vaccinated friends contract Covid-19, even though the doses offer a critical extra layer of protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Kurt Markus, Photographer of Cowboys and Models, Is Dead at 75
description: He traveled the world and shot celebrities and fashion luminaries. But he never abandoned his roots in the open spaces of the American West.
content: The award-winning photographer Kurt Markus led a life and career that seemed as vast and varied as the Western landscapes he captured on film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: A ‘Moral Role in Society’ and Little Enforcement? You Have This Reporter’s Attention.
description: David Fahrenthold of The Times discusses why the world of nonprofit charities is prime for investigative reporting.
content: In 2017, David Fahrenthold, who was working for The Washington Post at the time, won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting on the Donald J. Trump Foundation’s misappropriation of charitable funds. (Two years later, President Trump had to pay $2 million to a group of charities as part of a settlement.) Exploring — and scrutinizing, when appropriate — the world of charities made Mr. Fahrenthold interested in diving even deeper, and in January, he joined The New York Times to investigate nonprofit organizations. He reported in May that a little-known United Nations agency had doled out millions of dollars in questionable grants and loans. His latest article, which he worked on with the Times journalists Julie Tate and Troy Closson, is about one man who was accused by prosecutors of operating a long-running charity fraud and getting dozens of fake charities approved by the Internal Revenue Service.
source.name: The New York Times

title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A four-bedroom house in San Diego, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1929 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles.
content: A four-bedroom house in San Diego, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1929 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Problem Decoded
description: The problem can now be solved on the original board.
content: The problem can now be solved on the original board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Burns
title: America Is Failing Refugees, and Itself
description: How the United States treats refugees is one of the greatest tests of the American experiment.
content: How the United States treats refugees is one of the greatest tests of the American experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and Reuters
title: Shooting at Fourth of July Parade Leaves Several Dead
description: Police said multiple people were killed and dozens were wounded after a gunman opened fire from a rooftop onto a parade in Highland Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.
content: Police said multiple people were killed and dozens were wounded after a gunman opened fire from a rooftop onto a parade in Highland Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Recasting the Problem
description: June Huh found this problem much easier to solve.
content: June Huh found this problem much easier to solve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What I Learned While Talking to Strangers
description: Encounters with strangers; U.S. policy in Asia; what the police need; living in nature; artificial intelligence.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Last-Minute Menu for the Fourth
description: Enjoy Hawaiian mac salad alongside burgers, grilled vegetables or huli huli chicken.
content: Good morning. I remember a Fourth of July a few years ago when I flew into New York in the evening, and I could see fireworks all over the surrounding counties on the approach to the airport: soundless explosions of twinkling lights, beautiful and maybe even moving. (Emotions are heightened on planes.) When I got home, I made myself a hot dog and ate it with a glass of Champagne. Independence!
source.name: The New York Times
